questions.question: Why was the United Nations established after the Second World War?
questions.answer: The United Nations was established to instill the understanding that destructive wars must stop and to create a mechanism for establishing world peace[cite: 634, 636].

questions.question: What was the Atlantic Treaty?
questions.answer: The Atlantic Treaty was an agreement signed on 14th August 1941 between Winston Churchill and Franklin D. Roosevelt to set up a permanent mechanism for international security[cite: 638].

questions.question: What are the official languages of the United Nations?
questions.answer: The official languages are English, French, Russian, Spanish, Chinese, and Arabic[cite: 690].

questions.question: What is the primary significance of the General Assembly?
questions.answer: It serves as a platform for representatives of all member nations to discuss and make policy decisions on global issues[cite: 684].

questions.question: How are decisions made in the General Assembly?
questions.answer: Decisions in the General Assembly are taken by majority and are in the form of resolutions[cite: 682, 683].

questions.question: Who has 'Veto' power in the Security Council?
questions.answer: The five permanent members—America, Russia, England, France, and China—have the Veto power[cite: 694].

questions.question: What happens if a permanent member uses their Veto power?
questions.answer: If even one permanent member uses the Veto (gives a negative vote), the decision cannot be taken[cite: 696].

questions.question: What is the main responsibility of the Security Council?
questions.answer: The main responsibility is to maintain international peace and security[cite: 698].

questions.question: How are members of the Economic and Social Council selected?
questions.answer: The 54 members are selected by the General Assembly for a tenure of three years[cite: 706, 707].

questions.question: What are the main functions of the Secretariat?
questions.answer: The Secretariat carries out administrative tasks, organizes meetings, compiles information, and supplies information to the media[cite: 713, 722, 723, 724].

questions.question: Who heads the Secretariat and how are they chosen?
questions.answer: The Secretary General heads the Secretariat and is chosen by the General Assembly and Security Council for a five-year term[cite: 714, 720].

questions.question: What is the role of the International Court of Justice?
questions.answer: Its role is to settle disputes between member nations, interpret international law, and advise UN organs on legal issues[cite: 730, 731, 735].

questions.question: What is the International Criminal Court?
questions.answer: It is an international tribunal headquartered in The Hague that prosecutes individuals for crimes like genocide and war crimes[cite: 736, 737].

questions.question: Why was the Trusteeship Council established?
questions.answer: It was established to help developed nations administer undeveloped territories and assist them in attaining independence and democracy[cite: 739, 740].

questions.question: What are the Millennium Development Goals?
questions.answer: These are goals decided in 2000 to eliminate poverty, hunger, promote education, and improve health standards within a set time period[cite: 745, 749, 755].

questions.question: What is the role of UNICEF?
questions.answer: UNICEF works towards making nutritious food and health care available to children[cite: 757].

questions.question: What does UNESCO promote?
questions.answer: UNESCO promotes peace and security by fostering cooperation in education, science, and culture[cite: 759].

questions.question: How does the UN ensure peace in strife-torn areas?
questions.answer: The UN creates awareness about human rights, helps conduct elections, starts schools, and restores normalcy in conflict zones[cite: 766].

questions.question: What is the function of UN Peacekeeping Forces?
questions.answer: They create favorable circumstances for permanent peace in conflict-ridden areas and provide security[cite: 771, 773].

questions.question: Describe India's contribution to UN peacekeeping.
questions.answer: India has consistently sent troops to UN peacekeeping forces, including an all-woman peacekeeping force[cite: 783, 784].

questions.question: What issues has India raised on the UN platform?
questions.answer: India has raised issues like decolonization, disarmament, racial segregation, and problems of developing countries[cite: 780, 782].

questions.question: What is the 'Atlantic Treaty' related to?
questions.answer: It is related to the decision to set up a permanent mechanism for international security after WWII[cite: 638].

questions.question: How many countries drafted the UN Charter?
questions.answer: Representatives of fifty countries drafted the Charter of the United Nations[cite: 641].

questions.question: What is the status of member nations in the UN?
questions.answer: All member nations have the same status; there is no discrimination based on size, economy, or military power[cite: 661].

questions.question: Can the General Assembly make laws?
questions.answer: No, the General Assembly only passes resolutions; it does not make laws[cite: 683].

questions.question: Who elects the non-permanent members of the Security Council?
questions.answer: The General Assembly elects the non-permanent members of the Security Council[cite: 686].

questions.question: What is the tenure of a judge in the International Court of Justice?
questions.answer: Every judge has a tenure of nine years[cite: 728].

questions.question: What is the main objective of the Economic and Social Council?
questions.answer: Its main objective is to coordinate the economic and social policies of the United Nations[cite: 705].

questions.question: How often does the General Assembly meet?
questions.answer: The General Assembly meets in its session every year from September to December[cite: 681].

questions.question: What reform is India seeking in the Security Council?
questions.answer: India is making efforts to get permanent membership of the Security Council[cite: 703].

questions.question: Explain the principles of the United Nations.
questions.answer: The United Nations functions on specific principles. Firstly, all member nations have equal status regardless of their geographical size, economic strength, or military power[cite: 661]. Secondly, all members must respect the freedom and geographical unity of other nations[cite: 662]. Finally, all disputes and mutual differences among member nations must be solved through peaceful means[cite: 663].

questions.question: Describe the structure and voting process of the UN Security Council.
questions.answer: The Security Council consists of 15 members: five permanent (America, Russia, England, France, China) and ten non-permanent members elected every two years[cite: 691, 692, 694]. The five permanent members possess 'Veto power'. For any substantive decision to be passed, it requires the assent of all five permanent members plus four non-permanent members[cite: 695]. If a single permanent member casts a negative vote (veto), the decision cannot be taken[cite: 696].

questions.question: What are the key functions of the Economic and Social Council?
questions.answer: The Economic and Social Council coordinates UN economic and social policies[cite: 705]. Its functions include initiating global discussions on poverty, unemployment, and inequality[cite: 709]. It discusses women's empowerment, human rights, and global trade[cite: 710]. It also strives to establish cultural and educational cooperation internationally [cite: 711] and coordinates the work of affiliated organizations[cite: 712].

questions.question: Discuss the objectives of the United Nations.
questions.answer: The United Nations aims to establish international peace by taking necessary measures[cite: 650]. Its specific objectives are to establish friendly relations among nations [cite: 653], enhance international security by solving disputes [cite: 654], and safeguard and foster human rights and freedom[cite: 655]. Additionally, it aims to enhance economic cooperation at the international level[cite: 656].

questions.question: How does the United Nations work towards the preservation of peace?
questions.answer: The UN aims to settle conflicts peacefully using methods like appointing intermediaries, legal procedures, or arbitrators[cite: 761, 763]. If needed, it may use military means. In modern times, it focuses on human security against terrorism and religious conflict[cite: 764]. It works to prevent violence in strife-torn areas and restore normalcy by starting schools, conducting elections, and creating human rights awareness[cite: 766].

questions.question: Write a note on India's relationship and role in the United Nations.
questions.answer: India has been involved with the UN since before its establishment, participating in early conferences[cite: 779]. It has raised key issues like decolonization, disarmament, and racism—being the first to raise the racism issue in 1946[cite: 780, 781]. India leads discussions on developing countries' problems and actively sends troops, including an all-woman force, for UN peacekeeping missions[cite: 782, 783, 784]. India is also currently seeking permanent membership in the Security Council[cite: 703].

questions.question: Explain the Millennium Development Goals set by the UN.
questions.answer: In 2000, UN member nations agreed on goals for the new millennium[cite: 745]. These include eliminating poverty and hunger, providing primary education, and empowering women[cite: 749, 750, 751]. Other goals are reducing infant mortality, caring for pregnant women's health, fighting diseases like AIDS and malaria, and protecting the environment while fostering cooperation between developed and developing countries[cite: 752, 753, 754].
